elements.content: Structural defects in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have the potential to yield desirable properties that could not be achieved by “defect-free” crystals, but previous works in this area have focused on limited versions of defects due to the difficulty of detecting defects in MOFs. In this work, a modeling library containing 425 defective UiO-66 (UiO-66-Ds) with a comprehensive population (in terms of concentration and distribution) of missing-linker defects was created. Taking ethane–ethylene separation as a case study, we demonstrated that machine learning could provide data-driven insight into how the defects control the performance of UiO-66-Ds in adsorption, separation, and mechanical stability. We found that the missing-linker ratio in real materials could be predicted from the gravimetric surface area and pore volume, making it a useful complement for the challenges of directly measuring the defect concentration. We further identified the “privileged” UiO-66-Ds that were optimal in overall properties and provided decision trees as guidance to access and design these top performers. This work offers a general strategy for fully exploring the defects in MOFs, providing long-term opportunities for the development of defect engineering in the adsorption community.

elements.content: Structural defects are common in crystalline materials, which have been widely recognized to create interesting properties that cannot be achieved by the “ideal” crystals. In the zeolite community, defects have been studied for decades, where point defects alter the pore chemistry that can have decisive impacts on their performance in separation, transportation, and catalysis, while large-scale defects (e.g., stacking faults) expose a strong influence on diffusion and mechanical properties. These extensive studies of defects in zeolites provide an additional dimension for locally manipulating the material performances, in other words, “defect engineering”. As emerging porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great scientific interest due to their highly tunable porosity and multifunctionality. However, the ability to detect and control defects in MOFs is still in its infancy.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Structural defects are common in crystalline materials, which have been widely recognized to create interesting properties that cannot be achieved by the "ideal" crystals. In the zeolite community, defects have been studied for decades, where point defects alter the pore chemistry that can have decisive impacts on their performance in separation, transportation, and catalysis, while large-scale defects (e.g., stacking faults) expose a strong influence on diffusion and mechanical properties. These extensive studies of defects in zeolites provide an additional dimension for locally manipulating the material performances, in other words, "defect engineering". As emerging porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great scientific interest due to their highly tunable porosity and multifunctionality. However, the ability to detect and control defects in MOFs is still in its infancy.

elements.content: Like zeolites, various structural heterogeneities during the self-assembly of MOFs could lead to missing-linker or missing-cluster defects (analogous to oxygen and metal vacancies in zeolites). The deliberate introduction of these defects allows the modulation of external surfaces and local porosity or the creation of accessible open metal sites in MOFs that could aid in them outperforming their parent materials in various applications. Among the studies of defective MOFs, UiO-66 (see a) is a representative example, as its 12-connected fcu topology could carry considerable defects without suffering a great loss of mechanical stability, providing the opportunity for defect engineering. For instance, Wu et al. showed that ∼10% of missing-linker defects in UiO-66 could boost CO2 uptake by ∼50% at 35 bar. Wang et al. demonstrated the improved separation performance of Safranine T over Crystal Violet in UiO-66 because of the size-exclusion effects created by defects. Liu et al. showed that the improvement in the ring-opening reactivity of epoxide in defective UiO-type MOFs was associated with the missing-linker defects that were acting as reaction sites. Despite the versatility of defects in MOFs, the applicability of defect engineering in MOFs is hampered by multiple challenges. One of the most fundamental issues is the mechanical stability, as the degradation of the crystal could lead to an irreversible decline in material performance. Unfortunately, little about the mechanisms of this degradation associated with the amount of defects presented in MOFs has been learned.

elements.content: (a) Ideal structure of UiO-66 with 12-coordinated Zr6 metal clusters interconnected by benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) linkers in fcu topology. The green and yellow spheres denote the tetrahedral and octahedral cavities, respectively. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity. (b) Scheme for creating defective UiO-66 (UiO-66-Ds) with a range of missing-linker ratios and short-range orders (SROs) for quantifying the concentration and distribution of missing-linker defects. Linker-A and linker-B refer to the linkers to remain and those to be removed, respectively. SRO values of <0, 0, or >0 represent a uniformly ordering, random, or clustering arrangement of linker-B, respectively. Note that some extreme clustering missing-linker defects may lead to missing metal cluster defects.

elements.content: Previous efforts have been focused on probing defects in MOFs with various characteristics like atomic force microscopy (AFM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), confocal fluorescence microscopy (CFM), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), etc. It is worth noting that Han et al. have experimentally imaged the point defects in UiO-66 by HRTEM, which was previously considered as defect-free on the basis of N2 adsorption and PXRD data. Nevertheless, these experimental techniques still cannot be attained to quantify the distribution of defects, not to mention the possibility of exploring the diversity of defects in MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Previous efforts have been focused on probing defects in MOFs with various characteristics like atomic force microscopy (AFM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), confocal fluorescence microscopy (CFM), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), etc. It is worth noting that Han et al. have experimentally imaged the point defects in UiO-66 by HRTEM, which was previously considered as defect-free on the basis of N2 adsorption and PXRD data. Nevertheless, these experimental techniques still cannot be attained to quantify the distribution of defects, not to mention the possibility of exploring the diversity of defects in MOFs.

elements.content: From this perspective, it would be useful to apply computational methods to efficiently and quantitatively predict the tunable structural characteristics of defective MOFs and identify the defective candidates that may exhibit more desirable performance relative to those of the parent materials. However, a vast majority of the reported simulation studies of MOFs were based on defect-free structures, and only limited examples considered the effects of linker and cluster vacancies on adsorption and mechanical properties. These defects were assumed to be either randomly distributed or equally linker missed per metal cluster. The lack of statistical data strongly limits the performance of computational predictions associated with the defect concentration and distribution in MOFs.

However, a vast majority of the reported simulation studies of MOFs were based on defect-free structures, and only limited examples considered the effects of linker and cluster vacancies on adsorption and mechanical properties. These defects were assumed to be either randomly distributed or equally linker missed per metal cluster. The lack of statistical data strongly limits the performance of computational predictions associated with the defect concentration and distribution in MOFs.

elements.content: Machine learning-driven materials informatics, as a connection between data science and materials science, has attracted widespread interest theoretically and practically, due to not only its suitability for structure analysis on the microscale inherited from the classical molecular simulation but also its high efficiency in structure and property prediction based on the data integration by machine learning algorithms. In the MOF community, multiple machine learning algorithms like the support vector machine (SVM), decision tree (DT), and artificial neural network (ANN) have demonstrated satisfying accuracy in their predictions among the high-throughput screening in large libraries of MOFs. Experimentally accessible features like pore size, pore volume, and surface area are the most common descriptors for training machine learning models. Recent works also include topologies, chemical features, and newly developed descriptors to make the models universal and predictable. However, to the best of our knowledge, few works have considered the concentration and distribution of defects as descriptors to examine the nature of defects as well as their impacts on the adsorption performance and/or mechanical stability of MOFs.

elements.content: Herein, we present the quantitative predictions of the adsorption performance and mechanical stability of defective UiO-66 (UiO-66-D) by combining molecular simulation and machine learning in this work. 425 UiO-66-D structures with a broad range of concentrations and distributions of missing-linker defects are created, followed by the application to adsorptive separation of ethane–ethylene mixtures. Specifically, we collect a diverse set of textual, mechanical, and chemical features of the UiO-66-Ds from high-throughput calculations and examine their deviations from ideal UiO-66. This modeling library also allows us to access several interesting points that cannot be attained from experiment. First, the target properties (adsorption, separation, and mechanical robustness) of the UiO-66-Ds are quantitatively predicted by machine learning algorithms, with the aim of elucidating the key features as well as their underlying impacts on the properties. After fully exploring the predictability of machine learning, we further examine its capability to reproduce the missing-linker ratio in practical UiO-66 materials by means of readily accessible data from experiment. Finally, the “privileged” UiO-66-Ds integrating the optimal overall properties are predictably proposed. It is expected that identifying these candidates by the approach presented in this work would provide a feasible pathway for the design and screening of the top materials with novel defective structures and high performances, as well as the long-term development of “defect engineering”.

elements.content: The ideal UiO-66 (identity code RUBTAK01) used to create UiO-66-Ds is derived from the computation-ready experimental (CoRE) MOF database. We build the defective structures from 3 × 3 × 3 unit cells of ideal UiO-66, in which the benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) linkers are defined as linker-A and -B, referring to those that remain and those to be removed, respectively, as shown in b. The missing-linker ratio and short-range order (SRO) of linker-B are introduced to quantify the concentration and distribution of missing-linker defects in the material. The missing-linker ratio is the fractional concentration of linker-B in the structure. The missing-linker SRO is quantified by the Warren–Cowley parameter α to determine the occupation of linker-B. The Warren–Cowley parameters make up one of the simplest and oldest statistical models for describing a particular local disorder (i.e., SRO) in a system that deviated from the average on a long-term scale, as defined in . α j = 1 − P j A ( B ) x B where P j A(B) is the conditional probability of finding linker-B at the jth neighbor site given a linker-A and x B denotes the missing-linker (linker-B) ratio. Here we set j = 1 to identify the nearest neighbors for a given linker-A as the linkers bond to the shared metal centers [Zr6O4(OH)4]; thus, each linker in UiO-66 has 22 nearest neighbors. SRO values of <0, 0, or >0 represent whether the distribution of defects is uniformly ordered, random, or clustered, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Modeling Procedures

Creation of the Defective UiO-66 (UiO-66-D) Library

The ideal UiO-66 (identity code RUBTAK01) used to create UiO-66-Ds is derived from the computation-ready experimental (CoRE) MOF database. We build the defective structures from 3 × 3 × 3 unit cells of ideal UiO-66, in which the benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) linkers are defined as linker-A and -B, referring to those that remain and those to be removed, respectively, as shown in b. The missing-linker ratio and short-range order (SRO) of linker-B are introduced to quantify the concentration and distribution of missing-linker defects in the material. The missing-linker ratio is the fractional concentration of linker-B in the structure. The missing-linker SRO is quantified by the Warren-Cowley parameter α to determine the occupation of linker-B. The Warren-Cowley parameters make up one of the simplest and oldest statistical models for describing a particular local disorder (i.e., SRO) in a system that deviated from the average on a long-term scale, as defined in . 1       α   j   = 1 -     P   j   A  ( B )        x   B        where P  j  A(B) is the conditional probability of finding linker-B at the jth neighbor site given a linker-A and x B denotes the missing-linker (linker-B) ratio. Here we set j = 1 to identify the nearest neighbors for a given linker-A as the linkers bond to the shared metal centers [Zr6O4(OH)4]; thus, each linker in UiO-66 has 22 nearest neighbors. SRO values of <0, 0, or >0 represent whether the distribution of defects is uniformly ordered, random, or clustered, respectively.

elements.content: We note that the boundary limit of SRO depends on the size of the simulation volumes (see Table S1), but the largest volume we tested (6 × 6 × 6) has not yet accessed the finite size effects on the SRO. A recent work of mixed-linker ZIFs showed that the finite size effects have only negligible impacts on the diffusion of adsorbates. Considering the time and computational costs in simulating larger volumes, we choose a 3 × 3 × 3 simulation cell for modeling the defective structures and ideal UiO-66. Thus, the target SRO is set from −0.10 to 0.38 (according to our tests in Table S1) with an interval of 0.02 for every given missing-linker ratio, and a range of missing-linker ratios is targeted from 0.1 to 0.9 with an interval of 0.05; therefore, 425 UiO-66-Ds were created. To achieve a specific SRO, a reverse Monte Carlo (RMC) algorithm is used (more details are given in section S1 of the Suporting Information). Once the target missing-linker ratio and SRO are determined, linker-B are removed with the dangling bonds terminated by hydroxy groups to maintain electrical neutrality, which has been reported in multiple studies. It should be noted that isolated metal centers may form when a large number of clustering linkers are removed (i.e., with all 12 linkers removed from a shared metal center). These metal centers are removed, and missing-cluster defects are left in the structures. As the 425 UiO-66-Ds are generated, we then optimize these defective structures and ideal UiO-66 with the universal force field (UFF) by the Forcite module in Materials Studio.

elements.content: As shown in , the structural features of UiO-66-Ds are readily calculated by Zeo++, the chemical features are computed by RASPA, and the mechanical features are calculated using the Forcite module in Materials Studio. The adsorption loadings of pure ethane and ethylene and those of their equimolar mixtures in UiO-66-Ds are calculated by grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations. UFF and TraPPE force fields are used to describe the adsorbents and adsorbates in the dispersion interactions, whereas the Coulombic interactions are described by Ewald summation, with atomic point charges of UiO-66-Ds calculated by the DDEC method and the charges of adsorbates taken from TraPPE. Good consistency is observed upon comparison of our calculated adsorption isotherms of pure ethane and ethylene in ideal UiO-66 with experimental results from the literature (see Figure S3), which allows a validation of our modeling method, force fields, and charges used to describe the adsorption properties through this work. In terms of equimolar mixtures, ethane selectivity at 0.1 bar is quantified as the ratio of single-component ethane and ethylene Henry’s coefficients. This Henry’s regime selectivity has been used as an efficient way to rapidly estimate the selectivity under the dilute conditions. Whereas the selectivity at 1.0 bar is directly computed by GCMC simulations, for the sake that the adsorbate−adsorbate interactions may be important in the adsorption of highly non-ideal mixtures. The mechanical properties of UiO-66-Ds, including bulk and shear moduli, are computed under the UFF by means of strain–stress tensors. More details about the calculations of properties can be found in section S2 of the Supporting Information. The calculation methods we used have been comprehensively applied in multiple recent high-throughput works, which provide good reproductivities for various experimental adsorptions.
elements.clean_text:
Property Calculations

As shown in , the structural features of UiO-66-Ds are readily calculated by Zeo++, the chemical features are computed by RASPA, and the mechanical features are calculated using the Forcite module in Materials Studio. The adsorption loadings of pure ethane and ethylene and those of their equimolar mixtures in UiO-66-Ds are calculated by grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations. UFF and TraPPE force fields are used to describe the adsorbents and adsorbates in the dispersion interactions, whereas the Coulombic interactions are described by Ewald summation, with atomic point charges of UiO-66-Ds calculated by the DDEC method and the charges of adsorbates taken from TraPPE. Good consistency is observed upon comparison of our calculated adsorption isotherms of pure ethane and ethylene in ideal UiO-66 with experimental results from the literature (see Figure S3), which allows a validation of our modeling method, force fields, and charges used to describe the adsorption properties through this work. In terms of equimolar mixtures, ethane selectivity at 0.1 bar is quantified as the ratio of single-component ethane and ethylene Henry's coefficients. This Henry's regime selectivity has been used as an efficient way to rapidly estimate the selectivity under the dilute conditions. Whereas the selectivity at 1.0 bar is directly computed by GCMC simulations, for the sake that the adsorbate-adsorbate interactions may be important in the adsorption of highly non-ideal mixtures. The mechanical properties of UiO-66-Ds, including bulk and shear moduli, are computed under the UFF by means of strain-stress tensors. More details about the calculations of properties can be found in section S2 of the Supporting Information. The calculation methods we used have been comprehensively applied in multiple recent high-throughput works, which provide good reproductivities for various experimental adsorptions.

Several machine learning algorithms derived from the Scikit-learn toolbox are trained by the descriptors listed in to predict the target properties of UiO-66-Ds. Six algorithms are examined: linear regression (LR, on the basis of Ridge regression), decision tree (DT), random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), k-nearest neighbors (kNN), and gradient boosting tree (GB). A very recent work by Ryther et al. is a good review of these machine learning algorithms, with a particular emphasis on their ability to identify top-performing MOFs in terms of adsorption.

Machine Learning Algorithms

Several machine learning algorithms derived from the Scikit-learn toolbox are trained by the descriptors listed in  to predict the target properties of UiO-66-Ds. Six algorithms are examined: linear regression (LR, on the basis of Ridge regression), decision tree (DT), random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), k-nearest neighbors (kNN), and gradient boosting tree (GB). A very recent work by Ryther et al. is a good review of these machine learning algorithms, with a particular emphasis on their ability to identify top-performing MOFs in terms of adsorption.

elements.content: During the machine leaning procedure, 80% of the library of UiO-66-Ds are randomly selected as a training set, and the remaining 20% as a test set. Model training is performed to mine the quantitative relationships between the descriptors and the target properties, while the test set is for evaluating the model performance by predicting new incoming data. During the training process, each model except LR is trained with a random search method to determine the hyperparameters that could yield the highest accuracy according to a 10-fold cross validation. After the training process, model performance is measured in the test set by several scoring characteristics, e.g., mean absolute error (MAE), mean square error (MSE), root-mean-square error (RMSE), and R 2, as described in –, where x i is the directly calculated or experimental value, y i is the value predicted by machine leaning, and y̅ is the average of the predicted values. MAE ( x , y ) = 1 n samples ∑ i = 1 n samples | x i − y i | MSE ( x , y ) = 1 n samples ∑ i = 1 n samples ( x i − y i ) 2 RMSE ( x , y ) = 1 n samples ∑ i = 1 n samples ( x i − y i ) 2 R 2 ( x , y ) = 1 − ∑ i = 1 n samples ( x i − y i ) 2 ∑ i = 1 n samples ( y i − y̅ ) 2

elements.content: It would be useful to have an initial understanding of the feature deviations in UiO-66-Ds caused by missing-linker defects. To this end, the relative features of UiO-66-Ds normalized by the corresponding data of ideal UiO-66 are summarized in . The absolute data and histograms are provided in Table S3 and Figures S4 and S5. It is remarkable that the defects give rise to diverse deviations in various features from ideal UiO-66. For instance, pore size (both PLD and LCD) and pore volume for most UiO-66-Ds are increased by the introduction of defects. Accordingly, worse adsorption uptake at 0.1 bar and improved uptake at 1.0 bar are observed for both ethane and ethylene, whereas ethane selectivities hold in a narrow range very close to that of ideal UiO-66.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Missing-Linker Defects Lead to Diverse Deviations from Ideal UiO-66

It would be useful to have an initial understanding of the feature deviations in UiO-66-Ds caused by missing-linker defects. To this end, the relative features of UiO-66-Ds normalized by the corresponding data of ideal UiO-66 are summarized in . The absolute data and histograms are provided in Table S3 and Figures S4 and S5. It is remarkable that the defects give rise to diverse deviations in various features from ideal UiO-66. For instance, pore size (both PLD and LCD) and pore volume for most UiO-66-Ds are increased by the introduction of defects. Accordingly, worse adsorption uptake at 0.1 bar and improved uptake at 1.0 bar are observed for both ethane and ethylene, whereas ethane selectivities hold in a narrow range very close to that of ideal UiO-66.

elements.content: Box and whisker plot for the features of UiO-66-Ds normalized by the corresponding data of ideal UiO-66. The red dashed line represents the features of ideal UiO-66 as benchmarks to the defective structures. The center line of each box is the median of the data, and the left and right short lines illustrate the minimum (Q1 – 1.5 × IQR) and maximum value (Q3 + 1.5 × IQR), respectively. Q1, lower quartile; Q3, upper quartile; IQR (interquartile range) = Q3 – Q1. Outliers beyond this range are denoted as red dots. The feature labels are identical to those in Table .

elements.content: It is not surprising that the bulk and shear moduli uniformly decrease with defect concentration, but >50% (median) of UiO-66-Ds maintain at least 50% of the mechanical strength of the ideal UiO-66. Although UiO-66 has been widely studied as a benchmark with exceptional mechanical stability, the reported experimental and/or computational bulk moduli of “perfect” UiO-66 show a great deal of variation from 17 to 42. Such variation may be associated with defects in the real material and/or the force field-based calculation. Nonetheless, our results cover this variation [bulk modulus of 41.5 GPa in perfect UiO-66 and average value of 16.8 GPa in UiO-66-Ds (see Table S3)], which indicates that our models should provide physically meaningful predictions.

elements.content: To better visualize the impacts of defect concentration and distribution on material performance, we map the target properties as functions of missing-linker ratio and SRO in . Analogous maps for other features are provided in Figure S6. The structure with a missing-linker ratio of 0.3 and a SRO of −0.08 achieves the maximum working capacity for both adsorbates, ∼2-fold outperforming the ideal UiO-66 (see Table S3). When the ratio increases to >0.5, the SRO seems to have a limited influence on the working capacity. It is likely that a certain amount of random defects can provide additional adsorption sites and low-resistance diffusion pathways through the structure, but the excessively clustering defects may in turn weaken the adsorption affinity by creating large pores. For the top performers of separation at varying pressures, defects are nearly identical in concentration (missing-linker ratio of 0.1) but varied in distribution (SROs of 0.36 and −0.06 at 0.1 and 1.0 bar, respectively), implying that ethane selectivity is more sensitive to defect distribution as the pressure changes.

Note that the structures that did not converge in mechanical calculations are left blank in the maps of bulk and shear moduli.

Note that the structures that did not converge in mechanical calculations are left blank in the maps of bulk and shear moduli.

elements.content: Both bulk and shear moduli decrease almost linearly with an increasing missing-linker ratio, consistent with previous experimental results. At a given missing-linker ratio, both moduli exhibit fluctuations and are prone to increase at some certain missing-linker SROs. This observation may be attributed to the symmetric arrangement of missing-linker defects, which could create one-dimensional channels or local reo-type pores that allow the stability of the structure to be preserved exceptionally intact because the wall constructing these additional spaces remains reinforced by the surrounding linkers. It should be noted that some UiO-66-Ds at high missing-linker ratios fail to converge in mechanical calculations. This could be associated with the vast removal of linkers creating gaps through the supercell or isolated clusters (see Figure S7) that may lead to a loss of crystallinity. These cases make up ∼10% of the library (43 of 425 structures) and are excluded from the analysis below.

elements.content: With the goal of understanding the diverse deviation caused by defects, another interesting point to address is the degree of correlation between the pairwise features in the library. The Pearson correlation coefficients (PCCs) of some features are summarized in . A value of +1, −1, or 0 indicates total positive, total negative, or no linear correlation, respectively. The full version of the PCC matrix is shown in Figure S8, and the analogous Spearman ranking correlation coefficient (SRCC) matrix is provided in Figure S9 to illustrate the linear/nonlinear correlation. As shown in , nearly all of the structural features, including the missing-linker ratio (indexed from 1 to 7), show a strong positive linear correlation with each other; a similar trend is also observed in chemical and mechanical features (indexed from 10 to 21). A notable outlier from this simple trend is the framework density, which is reasonable because the dense structure could usually confer high mechanical stability. On the contrary, the relationships between structural properties and chemical/mechanical properties exhibit a negative linear correlation. These observations suggest that increasing the defect concentration in UiO-66 can improve the structurally related features (e.g., surface area, pore volume, etc.) but may be detrimental to working capacities, selectivities, and mechanical robustness. Although the performance of UiO-66 could be tuned in a wide range by the concentration and distribution of defects (see ), the missing-linker SRO seems to correlate inconspicuously with other features.

elements.content: One of our aims is to explore whether we could quantitatively capture the properties that are of interest in defective materials by means of a more rapid method related to experiment and/or classical molecular simulations. Due to the efficient nature of machine learning, investigating its accuracy in predicting UiO-66-D properties is desired both theoretically and experimentally. To this end, six machine learning models are trained with all of the descriptors listed in .
elements.clean_text:
Predictions of the Target Properties by Machine Learning

One of our aims is to explore whether we could quantitatively capture the properties that are of interest in defective materials by means of a more rapid method related to experiment and/or classical molecular simulations. Due to the efficient nature of machine learning, investigating its accuracy in predicting UiO-66-D properties is desired both theoretically and experimentally. To this end, six machine learning models are trained with all of the descriptors listed in .

elements.content: The parity plots in compare the calculated properties with the predicted results by the best performing model for every target property. Values of R 2 are calculated to provide a quantitative comparison between the models. The other scoring characteristics are listed in Tables S4–S9; the comparable level of accuracy between the training and testing sets indicates that there is no overfitting in these models. It is not surprising that the working capacity, selectivity at 0.1 bar, and moduli can be accurately reproduced by a simple LR model, associated with the relatively high PCC value between the descriptors and the target properties (see ). The selectivity at 1.0 bar seems to be more difficult to predict than others. This is reasonable as this GCMC-calculated selectivity may be influenced by the adsorbate–adsorbate interactions that alter the binary adsorption from ideal conditions. Analogous predictions of the missing-linker ratio and SRO are provided in Tables S10 and S11. As would be expected, the LR could predict the exact missing-linker ratio as in the test set [R 2 = 1 (see Table S10)]. An interesting observation is that the SVM can predict the SRO with high accuracy [R 2 > 0.9 (see Table S11 and Figure S10)], despite the relatively low PCC of SRO with respect to all descriptors (see ). On the basis of such observations, we feel that machine learning could be a simulation-free alternative to rapidly estimate the target properties of defective materials or features like the concentration and distribution of defects that are difficult to access experimentally.

elements.content: By means of the best performing models, the contribution (relative importance) of each descriptor in predicting the target properties could be obtained as well without any human interference, as summarized in . Note that the contributions of these factors to a given target property could be mutually influenced among the descriptors, as they are obtained from the machine learning models trained with multiple descriptors, which differ from the PCC coefficients in that reflect only the linear correlation exclusively between pairwise features. As would be expected, Henry’s coefficients (both ethane and ethylene) in a exhibit markedly greater importance than other descriptors in predicting the adsorption and separation properties. In the case of the selectivity at 1.0 bar, however, various features like GSA (23.5%), TDU (15.5%), DUC (8.9%), and Zr percentage (9.2%) seem to make non-negligible contributions. This observation is consistent with the results observed in , where the GCMC-calculated selectivity involves the impacts of adsorbate–adsorbate interactions and is in need of more descriptors for the prediction.

elements.content: It is worth noting that the missing-linker SRO responds to only a limited number of properties (see a, e.g., selectivity at 1.0 bar), whereas the missing-linker ratio exhibits a broad range of contributions to the target properties we examined. This result also exhibits reasonable consistency with the PCC/SRCC matrix shown in and Figure S9. With these observations in hand, we believe that efforts to control defect concentration should be relatively more effective than efforts to control the defect distribution in manipulating the properties of UiO-66. We further summarize the importance in predicting the missing-linker ratio and SRO in b. As would be expected, multiple features are needed to predict SRO, while the prediction of the missing-linker ratio seems to be more straightforward as only TDU and the number of C atoms are appreciably important. However, measuring atom numbers is not an experimental routine, and there are essentially no experimental data of this kind as descriptors to predict the defect concentration. This point is addressed below, where new machine learning models are trained using experimentally easy-to-access descriptors.

elements.content: Previous experimental studies must indirectly identify defects in MOFs through TGA or the potentiometric titration method, because traditional in situ characteristics like X-ray diffraction do not allow us to probe such minor structural changes that deviated from periodic lattice. As has demonstrated the significance of the defect concentration in controlling the properties of UiO-66-Ds, it would be interesting to consider whether the missing-linker ratio in real material could be predicted from easy-to-access features. From this perspective, new models are trained with all possible two-feature combinations derived from GSA, VSA, PLD, LCD, and pore volume (see Figure S11 and Table S12). We find that the combination of GSA and pore volume yields the best overall accuracies, with R 2 values of >0.98 in the models we examined. That is, in the absence of other features, it is still possible to capture the information on defects if the real defective materials follow a comparable structural relevance as described by our modeling library. We then feed the trained models with the experimental GSA and pore volume taken from the literature to predict the missing-linker ratio in real materials. Although an analogous workflow is applied for predicting the missing-linker SRO (see Table S13 and Figure S12), because there are essentially no experimental data of defect distributions to which we can compare, it is not possible to determine whether our predicted SROs are reliable.
elements.clean_text:
Quantification of the Missing-Linker Ratio in Real Materials

Previous experimental studies must indirectly identify defects in MOFs through TGA or the potentiometric titration method, because traditional in situ characteristics like X-ray diffraction do not allow us to probe such minor structural changes that deviated from periodic lattice. As  has demonstrated the significance of the defect concentration in controlling the properties of UiO-66-Ds, it would be interesting to consider whether the missing-linker ratio in real material could be predicted from easy-to-access features. From this perspective, new models are trained with all possible two-feature combinations derived from GSA, VSA, PLD, LCD, and pore volume (see Figure S11 and Table S12). We find that the combination of GSA and pore volume yields the best overall accuracies, with R 2 values of >0.98 in the models we examined. That is, in the absence of other features, it is still possible to capture the information on defects if the real defective materials follow a comparable structural relevance as described by our modeling library. We then feed the trained models with the experimental GSA and pore volume taken from the literature to predict the missing-linker ratio in real materials. Although an analogous workflow is applied for predicting the missing-linker SRO (see Table S13 and Figure S12), because there are essentially no experimental data of defect distributions to which we can compare, it is not possible to determine whether our predicted SROs are reliable.

elements.content: compares our predicted missing-linker ratio versus the experimental data. Detailed data are listed in Table S14. We quantify the linear correlation between prediction and experiment with the Pearson correlation coefficients (PCCs), with the best-fitting line of the form y = Ax + B, where x and y are the predicted and experimental results, respectively, and A and B are the fitted parameters. RMSE is calculated to provide a fair comparison between the models. As one would expect, the positive value of PCC in indicates that our trained models rationally predict the trend of experimental data, but the non-zero values of A and B also illustrate the deviation from perfect correspondence. This deviation may come from the force field-based calculations and/or the uncertain nature of experimental procedures. These experimental missing-linker ratios are estimated from TGA data on the basis of a temperature that determines the beginning of crystal degradation. This temperature, however, varies not only with the modulators applied in the synthesis process but also with the procedures used by different researchers. Also, the coordinated groups used to terminate the dangling bonds in defect sites could vary with modulators, as well, leading to variations in the measured GSA and pore volume even at identical concentrations of defects.

elements.content: On the basis of RMSE, it seems that the most accurate predictions come from LR, but its relatively low PCC indicates that this simple model is insufficient to capture the tendency of experimental data. In contrast, the kNN (PCC = 0.831) and SVM (PCC = 0.821) models exhibit good overall fittings, and their accuracies could be further improved with the predicted results scaled by the corresponding PCC linear correlations (see Figure S13). Essentially, the RMSE of the scaled results decreases to 0.0432 and 0.0442 for kNN and SVM, respectively. Although outliers are observed at relatively high missing-linker ratios, considering the challenges and uncertain nature of experiment in measuring the defects of MOFs, our calculations show that the scaled kNN and SVM models provide a rapid way to estimate the defect concentrations in real materials with fair accuracy. It would be clearly useful to develop better models considering the variations in experiment and improve the prediction accuracy shown in .

elements.content: By understanding the capability of machine learning in reproducing the missing-linker ratio in real materials, we expect to provide a more intuitive map for experimental researchers to access the defect concentration without advanced knowledge of machine learning or computational simulations. To achieve this, response surfaces are plotted in and Figure S14 by feeding all possible combinations of GSA and pore volume to the trained models derived from . The blue and red spheres indicate the calculated and experimental data, respectively.

elements.content: The response surfaces of LR, kNN, DT, RF, and GB shown in Figure S14 seem to respond poorly to the combinations that are not included in our library. In the case of SVM (see ), the blue and red spheres are located close to the response surface, which indicates that SVM can provide meaningful predictions in both our modeling library and real materials. Despite some combinations not presenting in our modeling library are less reliable, efforts to analyze these kinds allow an approximate estimation of defect concentrations when we explore real materials that may exhibit these specific features. For instance, the structure with a relatively large pore volume (1.6 cm3/g) and a small surface area (1500 m2/g) is not in our library, but it is likely to have a missing-linker ratio of 0.7. Another important observation is that the SVM response surface exhibits a continuous and monotonous tendency, so any combination of GSA and pore volume would correspond to only a unique missing-linker ratio value. This may be a rapid and straightforward alternative to experimentally measuring the defect concentrations in real materials, especially when the experimental data of GSA and pore volume are available.

elements.content: Previous efforts have focused on predicting the target properties and defect concentrations of UiO-66-Ds. It would be more interesting to explore whether some UiO-66-Ds exist that are “privileged” to integrate the optimal adsorption capacity, selectivity, and mechanical stability, the properties that are critical for applicability. Identifying such structures would also yield beneficial guidance to control the overall performance of MOFs by defect engineering.
elements.clean_text:
Identification of Privileged UiO-66-Ds and Guidance for Defect Engineering

Previous efforts have focused on predicting the target properties and defect concentrations of UiO-66-Ds. It would be more interesting to explore whether some UiO-66-Ds exist that are "privileged" to integrate the optimal adsorption capacity, selectivity, and mechanical stability, the properties that are critical for applicability. Identifying such structures would also yield beneficial guidance to control the overall performance of MOFs by defect engineering.

elements.content: To access the top-performing UiO-66-Ds, we summarize the ethane working capacity, selectivity, and bulk modulus of the UiO-66-D library in . An analogous plot related to shear modulus is provided in Figure S15. The results in provide a general view of performance in all UiO-66-Ds; the structures in the top right area of each panel exhibit not only more desirable working capacity and selectivity but also comparable mechanical stability with respect to ideal UiO-66. These privileged structures have relatively low concentrations of defects (missing-linker ratios of 0.2–0.3) for both high and low pressures, but the defects are prone to be distributed randomly (SRO = 0.02) at 1.0 bar and ordered (SRO > 0.1) at 0.1 bar. This counterintuitive observation is interesting. As we have mentioned, ordering defects could create one-dimensional channels when the missing linkers are arranged symmetrically. These one-dimensional channels in MOFs are more likely to show promise in separation at low loadings, which has recently been shown by a comprehensive analysis of separation of diverse binary mixtures in a large library of MOFs.

elements.content: Having observed that the privileged UiO-66-Ds exist, we aimed to determine thresholds to quantitatively identify these specific structures. It is obvious that the UiO-66-Ds with improved ethane working capacity are promising (85% of the library), but most UiO-66-Ds underperform their parent in selectivity and bulk modulus (see ). We define the promising candidates for separation as those that exceeded 95% of the ideal selectivity (35% of the library), and the threshold is set to 60% for bulk modulus (30% of the library). The previously reported bulk modulus of UiO-66 varies from 17 to 42; that is, the real samples could hold the crystallinity with at least 40% (17 of 42) of the ideal bulk modulus. Considering the importance of mechanical stability in process conditions, we feel that >60% of the ideal bulk modulus is likely to be adequate for applicability. On the basis of these thresholds, we catalog the UiO-66-Ds into three categories: “good”, “satisfying”, and “poor” (see section S3 of the Supporting Information for more details). The top 10 privileged structures at 0.1 and 1.0 bar are summarized in Tables S15 and S16. These top performers could have up to twice the working capacity of and selectivity comparable to that of ideal UiO-66, with an only 10% loss of mechanical stability.

elements.content: To provide straightforward guidance to access different categories of UiO-66-Ds, decision tree (DT) classifiers are trained with all possible combinations of descriptors that are experimentally easy to access, including LCD, PLD, GSA, and pore volume. F1 scores are used to measure the model performance for correctly cataloging the structures into specific categories. The full versions of the best performing DTs are shown in Figure S16, with F1 scores being >0.8 for both 0.1 and 1.0 bar (see Tables S17 and S18).
elements.clean_text: To provide straightforward guidance to access different categories of UiO-66-Ds, decision tree (DT) classifiers are trained with all possible combinations of descriptors that are experimentally easy to access, including LCD, PLD, GSA, and pore volume. F1 scores are used to measure the model performance for correctly cataloging the structures into specific categories. The full versions of the best performing DTs are shown in Figure S16, with F1 scores being >0.8 for both 0.1 and 1.0 bar (see Tables S17 and S18).

elements.content: We take the best performing DT at 0.1 bar for detailed analysis. As shown in , at least six layers of the tree and four descriptors are needed to access all possible “good” categories. It is associated with the small amount of “good” candidates (∼10% of the library), which makes them relatively more difficult to classify. The tree model also highlights some implications that may be significant for defect engineering. (I) GSA (80.4% important) and pore volume (16.2% important) are the two of the most sensitive factors out of the other examined descriptors to determine whether the defects improve the performance of UiO-66. (II) Controlling GSA and pore volume within the “optimal” regions is more likely to achieve the privileged performance. For instance, the structures with GSA values in the range of 1153.4–1627.1 m2/g and pore volumes in the range of 0.54–0.58 cm3/g could have a probability of at least 61.5% to fall in the “good” categories. (III) Although PLD and LCD have limited importance, they could be used to eliminate the “poor” candidates. Among the structures in the “optimal” regions of GSA and pore volume, the ones with PLDs of >5.5 Å or LCDs of <8.7 Å could have a probability of 33.3% or 5.3% of being “poor” (see Figure S16 for more details).

elements.content: Because PLD (2.4%) and LCD (1.0%) have limited contributions, our four-descriptor DT model () also allows us to catalog the real materials in from only experimental GSA and pore volume, as summarized in Table S19. These predictions are quite consistent with those of a two-descriptor (GSA and pore volume) model. Although there is no reported bulk modulus for any UiO-66 examples with measured ethane–ethylene adsorption, we rank a real material by its experimental ethane working capacity and selectivity (see Figure S17). The “satisfying” region in which the material falls is reasonably consistent with our DT predictions [probabilities of ∼80% and ∼20% as “satisfying” at 1.0 and 0.1 bar, respectively (see Table S19)].

elements.content: Additionally, we note that UiO-66 is more consistent in the measured BET surface area (844.6–1169.7 m2/g) than HKUST-1 (932.6–1486.0 m2/g) based on a comprehensive analysis of experimental N2 isotherms from the NIST/ARPA-E Adsorption Database (see Table S20 for more details). Because N2 adsorption is generally the basis of quantifying surface area, pore volume, and pore size in experiments, the higher reproducibility of measurements in UiO-66 means that feeding our models with these structural descriptors should give relatively stable predictions.

elements.content: This study has been one of the initial attempts to systematically examine the missing-linker defects in UiO-66 and their relationships with material properties, aiming to extend our current knowledge of defects in MOFs. We have created a modeling library of 425 UiO-66-Ds with a broad population of missing-linker defects, followed by the applications to ethane–ethylene separation. We demonstrated that machine learning could be an efficient and “simulation-free” way to elucidate the key features governing the target properties (adsorption, separation, and mechanical stability). Fully exploring the library by machine learning also allows one to capture some vital implications. Controlling defect concentration rather than distribution was found to be more significant in tuning the overall properties. The missing-linker ratio in real UiO-66-D materials could be predicted from only GSA and pore volume. This finding is extremely interesting, as it is expected to be a complementary solution for the challenges of measuring the defect concentration experimentally. Finally, we provided straightforward guidance to access the privileged UiO-66-Ds with optimal overall properties or to avoid the poor candidates.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

This study has been one of the initial attempts to systematically examine the missing-linker defects in UiO-66 and their relationships with material properties, aiming to extend our current knowledge of defects in MOFs. We have created a modeling library of 425 UiO-66-Ds with a broad population of missing-linker defects, followed by the applications to ethane-ethylene separation. We demonstrated that machine learning could be an efficient and "simulation-free" way to elucidate the key features governing the target properties (adsorption, separation, and mechanical stability). Fully exploring the library by machine learning also allows one to capture some vital implications. Controlling defect concentration rather than distribution was found to be more significant in tuning the overall properties. The missing-linker ratio in real UiO-66-D materials could be predicted from only GSA and pore volume. This finding is extremely interesting, as it is expected to be a complementary solution for the challenges of measuring the defect concentration experimentally. Finally, we provided straightforward guidance to access the privileged UiO-66-Ds with optimal overall properties or to avoid the poor candidates.

elements.content: Special attention should be paid to the universality of our approach. The amount of experimental data from the open literature may be inadequate to fully clarify the capability of machine learning for predicting defects in MOFs. Nonetheless, our trained models have reproduced the experimental results with fair accuracy. Our models described the stability of static UiO-66-Ds in the presence of binary mixtures, whereas the long-term stability of the material may suffer from defect evolution caused by multicomponent effects under process conditions. Despite detection of defects in MOFs remaining experimentally challenging, this study represents a significant step toward a data-driven analysis of defects and provide a useful reference for the development of defect engineering in MOFs and related materials with respect to practical adsorption and separation processes.

Our models described the stability of static UiO-66-Ds in the presence of binary mixtures, whereas the long-term stability of the material may suffer from defect evolution caused by multicomponent effects under process conditions. Despite detection of defects in MOFs remaining experimentally challenging, this study represents a significant step toward a data-driven analysis of defects and provide a useful reference for the development of defect engineering in MOFs and related materials with respect to practical adsorption and separation processes.

cln_elements.content: (a) Ideal structure of UiO-66 with 12-coordinated Zr6 metal clusters interconnected by benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) linkers in fcu topology. The green and yellow spheres denote the tetrahedral and octahedral cavities, respectively. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity. (b) Scheme for creating defective UiO-66 (UiO-66-Ds) with a range of missing-linker ratios and short-range orders (SROs) for quantifying the concentration and distribution of missing-linker defects. Linker-A and linker-B refer to the linkers to remain and those to be removed, respectively. SRO values of <0, 0, or >0 represent a uniformly ordering, random, or clustering arrangement of linker-B, respectively. Note that some extreme clustering missing-linker defects may lead to missing metal cluster defects.

cln_elements.content: Box and whisker plot for the features of UiO-66-Ds normalized by the corresponding data of ideal UiO-66. The red dashed line represents the features of ideal UiO-66 as benchmarks to the defective structures. The center line of each box is the median of the data, and the left and right short lines illustrate the minimum (Q1 – 1.5 × IQR) and maximum value (Q3 + 1.5 × IQR), respectively. Q1, lower quartile; Q3, upper quartile; IQR (interquartile range) = Q3 – Q1. Outliers beyond this range are denoted as red dots. The feature labels are identical to those in Table .

cln_elements.content: Contour maps as a function of missing-linker ratio and SRO referring to (a and d) the working capacity (WC) of ethane and ethane in mixtures, (b and e) the selectivity of ethane over ethylene (SE) at 0.1 and 1.0 bar, and (c and f) bulk and shear moduli. cln_elements.content: Parity plots comparing the computationally calculated properties vs the results predicted by machine learning from the best performing models referring to (a and d) the working capacity (WC) of ethane and ethylene in mixtures, (b and e) the selectivity of ethane (SE) at 0.1 and 1.0 bar, and (c and f) bulk and shear moduli. Models are trained with all of the descriptors listed in Table . The diagonal red dashed line indicates perfect correspondence. LR, linear regression; RF, random forest.

Models are trained with all of the descriptors listed in Table  . The diagonal red dashed line indicates perfect correspondence. LR, linear regression; RF, random forest.

cln_elements.content: Feature importance in the prediction of (a) the ethane and ethylene working capacity (WC), selectivity of ethane (SE) at 0.1 and 1.0 bar, and bulk/shear moduli and (b) the missing-linker ratio and SRO. Note that the importance of the missing-linker ratio and SRO is marked as zero upon their prediction. The feature importance to predict WCs, SE at 0.1 bar, bulk/shear moduli, and missing-linker ratio are generated from the LR model; while the information towards SE at 1.0 bar and SRO is generated from RF and SVM model, respectively. LR, linear regression; RF, random forest; SVM, support vector machine.

LR, linear regression; RF, random forest; SVM, support vector machine.

cln_elements.content: Parity plots comparing the experimental missing-linker ratio ,− vs the predicted results by feeding experimental GSA and pore volumes to the trained models of (a) LR, (b) DT, (c) SVM, (d) RF, (e) kNN, and (f) GB. The diagonal red dashed line in each panel indicates perfect correspondence, while the solid line and the equation indicate the linear correlation of the best-fitted Pearson correlation coefficients (PCCs). The PCC and RMSE are shown. LR, linear regression; DT, decision tree; SVM, support vector machine; RF, random forest; kNN, k-nearest neighbors; GB, gradient boosting tree.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Parity plots comparing the experimental missing-linker ratio ,-    vs the predicted results by feeding experimental GSA and pore volumes to the trained models of (a) LR, (b) DT, (c) SVM, (d) RF, (e) kNN, and (f) GB. The diagonal red dashed line in each panel indicates perfect correspondence, while the solid line and the equation indicate the linear correlation of the best-fitted Pearson correlation coefficients (PCCs). The PCC and RMSE are shown. LR, linear regression; DT, decision tree; SVM, support vector machine; RF, random forest; kNN, k-nearest neighbors; GB, gradient boosting tree.

cln_elements.content: Response surface of the SVM model for prediction of the missing-linker ratio using all of the possible combinations of gravimetric surface area (GSA) and pore volume. The surface is color-coded by the values of the missing-linker ratio. The blue and red spheres denote the GCMC-calculated data and the experimental data, respectively. The surface is transparent so the experimental data points behind the surface can be read.

cln_elements.content: Scatter plots for the structures in the library of UiO-66-Ds referring to ethane work capacity and selectivity at (a and b) 1.0 bar and (c and d) 0.1 bar. The size of data points indicates the bulk modulus, and the colors denote the values of (a and c) the missing-linker ratio and (b and d) the SRO. The value for ideal UiO-66 (empty red circle) is plotted for reference.
cln_elements.clean_text: 9  Scatter plots for the structures in the library of UiO-66-Ds referring to ethane work capacity and selectivity at (a and b) 1.0 bar and (c and d) 0.1 bar. The value for ideal UiO-66 (empty red circle) is plotted for reference.

cln_elements.content: Best decision tree (DT) model trained with PLD, LCD, GSA, and pore volume to access different categories of UiO-66-Ds integrating the performance of ethane working capacity, ethane selectivity at 0.1 bar, and bulk modulus. Categories of “good”, “satisfying”, and “poor” are colored green, yellow, and red circles, respectively. The values at the terminal nodes are the highest probabilities that the structures fall into the specific categories. PLD, pore limiting diameter; LCD, largest cavity diameter; GSA, gravimetric surface area.
